entry.title: The Restricted Three-Body Problem Part 1
entry.content:
Introduction

Consider two of the bodies move in a circular orbit with the same angular velocity, and they have a common of mass and a constant distance. Compared with the other two objects, the mass of the third body is negligible and taken as a massless small body (i.e. asteroids or satellite)\(^{[3]}\). Then, the motion of the third body is subject to the gravitational influence of two masses, but the third body can't affect the motion of two masses. This is called the restricted three-body problem.

The general restricted three-body problem is complex and chaotic, even small changes in initial conditions lead to a widely different result. Therefore, the solution must be obtained by numerical analysis. In application, it's used for space missions, such as a spacecraft moving to planets, or from Earth to the moon\(^{[3]}\). The mass of a small spacecraft is affected by planets and satellites of the planet, but the planets don't feel the gravitational force from a small spacecraft apparently\(^{[3]}\).

Let define the unit of mass in this system \[\begin{equation} \label{eq1.1} \mu = G (m_1 + m_2) \end{equation}\]

Then the two mass are \[\begin{equation} \label{eq1.2} \mu_1 = G m_1= \frac{m_1}{m_1+m_2} \end{equation}\] \[\begin{equation} \label{eq1.3} \mu_2 =\bar\mu = G m_2= \frac{m_2}{m_1+m_2} \end{equation}\]

Set of axes \((x, y, z)\) in the inertial coordinate frame referred to the centre of mass between \(\mu_1\) and \(\mu_2\). Therefore, the position of the two masses in the inertial frame are \((x_1, y_1, z_1)\) and \((x_2, y_2, z_2)\) (see Figure ). The unit of length is the constant distance between the two masses. And the inertial frame follows the constant angular velocity with mean motion \(n\).

The equation of motion of the particle at the point \(P\) in the inertial frame are \[\begin{equation} \label{eq1} % the label is used to reference the equation \ddot x' = \mu_1 \cdot \frac{(x_1' - x')}{r_1^{3}} + \mu_2 \cdot \frac{(x_2' - x')}{r_2^{3}} \end{equation}\] \[\begin{equation} \label{eq2} \ddot y' = \mu_1 \cdot \frac{(y_1' - y')}{r_1^{3}} + \mu_2 \cdot \frac{(y_2' - y')}{r_2^{3}} \end{equation}\] \[\begin{equation} \label{eq3} \ddot z' = \mu_1 \cdot \frac{(z_1' - z')}{r_1^{3}} + \mu_2 \cdot \frac{(z_2' - z')}{r_2^{3}} \end{equation}\]

The distance in the inertial frame represents as following, \[\begin{equation} \label{eq4} r_1^2 = (x_1' - x')^2 + (y_1' - y')^2 + (z_1' - z')^2 \end{equation}\] \[\begin{equation} \label{eq5} r_2^2 = (x_2' - x')^2 + (y_2' - y')^2 + (z_2' - z')^2 \end{equation}\]

Now, considering a new rotating coordinate system (see Figure ) has the same origin as the inertial frame, set of axes \((x', y', z')\), the position of two masses are \[\begin{align*} (x_1, y_1, z_1) = (-\mu_2, 0, 0) \\ (x_2, y_2, z_2) = (\mu_1, 0, 0) \end{align*}\]

Therefore, the distances in Equation~ and Equation~ can be rewritten as in term of the rotating coordinate system \[\begin{equation} \label{eq6} \begin{split} r_1^2& = (x_1' - x)^2 + (y_1' - y)^2 + (z_1' - z)^2 \\ &= (-\mu_2 - x)^2 + y^2 + z^2 \\ &= (x + \mu_2)^2 + y^2 + z^2 \end{split} \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} \label{eq7} \begin{split} r_2^2& = (x_2' - x)^2 + (y_2' - y)^2 + (z_2' - z)^2 \\ &= (\mu_1-x)^2 + y^2 + z^2 \\ &= (x - \mu_1 )^2 + y^2 + z^2 \end{split} \end{equation}\]

NOTE:
> \(x, y\), and \(z \Rightarrow\) the inertial (sidereal) coordinate system
> \(x', y'\), and $ z' $ the rotating (synodic) coordinate system

The relation between the inertial and the rotating coordinate system can be expressed as a matrix form. The rotating system is related to the inertial system by the simple rotation.

\[\begin{equation} \label{eq8} \begin{bmatrix} x' \\y' \\z' \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \cos{nt} & -\sin{nt} & 0 \\ \sin{nt} & \cos{nt} & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x \\y \\z \end{bmatrix} \end{equation}\]

Equation becomes \[\begin{equation} \label{eq8.1} \begin{split} x' = x \cos{nt} - y \sin{nt} \end{split} \end{equation}\] \[\begin{equation} \label{eq8.2} \begin{split} y' = x \sin{nt} + y \cos{nt} \end{split} \end{equation}\] \[\begin{equation} \label{eq8.3} \begin{split} z' = z \end{split} \end{equation}\]

Then, differentiate \(x', y'\), and \(z'\) \[\begin{equation} \label{eq9} \begin{bmatrix} \dot x' \\\dot y' \\\dot z' \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \cos{nt} & -\sin{nt} & 0 \\ \sin{nt} & \cos{nt} & 0 \\ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} \dot{x} -ny \\ \dot{y}+nx \\ \dot z \end{bmatrix} \end{equation}\]

Equation becomes \[\begin{equation} \label{eq9.1} \begin{split} \dot x' &= \dot x \cos{nt} + xn (-\sin{nt}) - \dot y \cos{nt} - yn\cos{nt} \\ &= \cos{nt}\cdot (\dot x -ny) - \sin{nt} \cdot (\dot y + nx) \end{split} \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} \label{eq9.2} \begin{split} \dot y' &= \dot x \sin{nt} + xn(-\cos{nt}) + \dot y \cos{nt} + yn(-\sin{nt}) \\ &= \sin{nt}\cdot (\dot x -ny) + \cos{nt}\cdot (\dot y + nx) \end{split} \end{equation}\]

References

  1. Murray C D, Dermott S F.\(\textit{ Solar System Dynamics}.\) Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1999: 316
  2. Fowles and Cassiday.\(\textit{Analytical Mechanics}.\) Cengage Learning, 2004
  3. The circular restricted three-body problem. Carlo Nipoti, Dipartimento di Fisica e Astronomia, Universit`a di Bologna
  4. Lecture L18 - Exploring the Neighborhood: the Restricted Three-Body Problem
  5. The restricted three-body problem (1): Equation of motion, The Jacobi Integral, and The Tisserand Relation
  6. The restricted three-body problem (2): Lagrangian points and the stability analysis

entry.title: Install the Linux system on Windows
entry.content:
中文版

Step 1 啟用Windows Linux System

需要先啟用 Windows Linux Subsystem 功能。需在『開啟或關閉 Windows 功能中設定』，剛裝完畢後，需要重新開機。

Step 2 安裝Ubuntu

接著到Windows Store 裡就有 Ubuntu App 可以選擇安裝

安裝成功後，就可以在 Windows 選單找到 Ubuntu App

  • 啟動Ubuntu後卻發現出現錯誤訊息…..

    這表示Windows-Subsystem-Linux (WSL)還沒打開，因此可以用接下來的方法解決。

Step 3 開啟PowerShell

輸入以下指令:

Enable-WindowsOptionalFeature -Online -FeatureName Microsoft-Windows-Subsystem-Linux

Step 4 啟動Ubuntu

安裝成功！

原本的 C/D/F 槽都 mount 在 /mnt 下

輸入cd /mnt/c/Users/*Name/Desktop

*Name: 根據自己的電腦名稱去修改

Step 5 更新套件

輸入 sudo apt-get update

Done!

English version

Step 1. Turn on Windows Linux Subsystem

  1. Press “Windows” + “R” keys simultaneously to open the Run prompt.
  2. Type in “Control Panel”
  3. Click on the “Programs and Features” option.
  4. Select the “Turn Windows Features On or OFF” option in the left pane.
  5. Scroll down and select “Windows Subsystem for Linux“
  6. 6.Click on “OK” to enable the feature.

Step 2 Install Ubuntu

  1. Open the Microsoft Store from the Start menu, and search for “Ubuntu” in the store
  2. To install , click it, and then click the “Get” or “Install” button to install it like any other Store application.

Step 3 Turning WSL ON Through PowerShell

  1. Search for PowerShell, right-click the top result, and select the Run as administrator option.

  2. Type the following command to enable the Linux subsystem and press Enter:

    Enable-WindowsOptionalFeature -Online -FeatureName Microsoft-Windows-Subsystem-Linux

    Type Y and press Enter to confirm and restart your computer.

Step 4 Open Ubuntu

  1. Open Start, and click it .

It works!

Step 5 Update

This is the first time you are using your system after installing, you should run the update command: sudo apt-get update

Done!

References

在 Windows 10 上跑 Ubuntu 18.04

How to Install and Use the Linux Bash Shell on Windows 10

How to Fix 'The WSL Optional Component is not Enabled. Please Enable it and Try again' Error on Ubuntu? - Appuals.com

Do you want to run Linux on Windows 10? Use WSL, here's how.

entry.title: The Restricted Three-Body Problem Part 2
entry.content:
Tisserand Relation

Consider a comet is not close with initial semi-major \(a\), eccentricity \(e\), inclination \(i\). After encountering Jupiter, the orbital element of the comet becomes semi-major \(a'\), eccentricity \(e'\), inclination \(i'\)

From the Jacobi integral \(C_J\), it remains constant value throughout the encounter with the masses \(^{[3]}\).

\[\begin{equation} \label{eq34} \begin{split} C_J &= 2V - v^2 \\ &= 2(\frac{\mu_1}{r_1}+\frac{\mu_2}{r_2}) + 2n(\dot x' y' - x' \dot y') - ( \dot x'^2 + \dot y'^2 + \dot z'^2 ) \\ \end{split} \end{equation}\]

For instance in Sun-Jupiter-comet problem, because the mass of Jupiter is smaller than Sun \((M_j \sim 10^{-3}M_\odot)\), we take \(\mu_1\) and \(r_1\) as the unity. refer oto eq. \(\ref{1}\) \[\begin{equation} \label{eq28.1} GM_\odot = \mu_1 = \mu \end{equation}\] \[\begin{equation} \label{eq28.1} r_1 = r \end{equation}\]

When the comet is not close to Jupiter, so that \(\frac{\mu_2}{r_2}\) term is always small to neglect the \(\mu_2\) term.

\[\begin{equation} \label{eq28.2} \frac{\mu_2}{r_2} \ll \frac{\mu_1}{r_1}=\frac{\mu}{r} \end{equation}\]

Where \(\mu_2 = GM_J\), \(r_2\) is the distance between Jupiter and the comet.

Then, we can consider the approximation of two-body problem between Sun and comet. From the orbital energy of Sun-comet two-body problem.

\[\begin{equation} \label{eq27} \begin{split} E = \frac{1}{2}(\ddot x^2 +\ddot y^2 +\ddot z^2 ) - \frac{G(M_\odot+ m_{comet})}{r_1} = -\frac{G(M_\odot+ m_{comet})}{2a} \end{split} \end{equation}\]

Here, \(G(M_\odot+ m_{comet}) \approx GM_\odot = \mu_1 = \mu\), so we calculate the velocity

\[\begin{equation} \label{eq28} \begin{split} v^2 = (\ddot x^2 +\ddot y^2 +\ddot z^2 ) = G(M_\odot+ m_{comet})(\frac{2}{r_1}-\frac{1}{a}) \end{split} \end{equation}\] \[\begin{equation} \label{eq30} \implies v^2 = \mu(\frac{2}{r}-\frac{1}{a}) \end{equation}\]

FoFor the angular momentum of the orbit \[\begin{equation} \label{eq31} \begin{split} \vec{h} &= \vec{r} \times \vec{\dot r} \\ &= n\sqrt{a(1-e^2)GM} \\ &= n\sqrt{a(1-e^2)\mu} \\ &= constant \end{split} \end{equation}\]

For the orbital energy, \[\begin{equation} \label{eq32} \begin{split} E &= \vec h \cdot \vec n \\ &= h \cdot n \cos{i} \\ &= n\sqrt{a(1-e^2)\mu} \cdot n \cos{i} \end{split} \end{equation}\]

the \(z'\) component of \(\vec h\) is given by \[\begin{equation} \label{eq33} 2n(\dot x' y' - x' \dot y') = h \cdot n \cos{i} \end{equation}\]

So, Jocobi integral \(C_J\) becomes \[\begin{equation} \label{eq34} \begin{split} C_J &= 2V - v^2 \\ &= 2(\frac{\mu_1}{r_1}+\frac{\mu_2}{r_2}) + 2n(\dot x' y' - x' \dot y') - ( \dot x'^2 + \dot y'^2 + \dot z'^2 ) \\ & ~~~~ (\because \frac{\mu_1}{r_1} \gg \frac{\mu_2}{r_2}\approx 0 , \mu_1\approx\mu, r_1 \approx r ) \\ &= \frac{2\mu}{r} + 2n(\dot x' y' - x' \dot y')- v^2 \\ &= \frac{2\mu}{r} + 2h \cdot n \cos{i} - (\frac{2\mu}{r}- \frac{\mu}{a}) \\ &= \frac{\mu}{a} + 2h \cdot n \cos{i} \\ &= \frac{\mu}{a} + 2 \cdot n\sqrt{a(1-e^2)\mu} \cdot n \cos{i} \\ & ~~~~ (\because n= 1) \\ &= \frac{\mu}{a} + 2\sqrt{a(1-e^2)\mu} \cdot \cos{i} \end{split} \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} \label{eq35} C_J = \frac{\mu}{a} + 2\sqrt{a(1-e^2)\mu} \cdot \cos{i} \approx constant \end{equation}\]

If the comet is not close to Jupiter, so that \(\frac{1}{r_2}\) is always small to neglect the \(\mu_2\) term in Equation , then we have

\[\begin{equation} \label{eq36} T_J = \frac{1}{2} C_J = \frac{\mu}{2a} + \sqrt{a(1-e^2)\mu} \cdot \cos{i} \approx constant \end{equation}\]

Therefore, the approximate relationship with the orbital element of the comet before and after encountering with Jupiter is given by \[\begin{equation} \label{eq37} T_J = \frac{\mu}{2a} + \sqrt{a(1-e^2)\mu} \cdot \cos{i} = \frac{\mu}{2a'} + \sqrt{a'(1-e'^2)\mu} \cdot \cos{i'} \end{equation}\]

By measuring the orbital elements of the comet, we can check whether the comet is new observed, or is the passage of a previously observed comet scattered by a close encounter with Jupiter.

References

  1. Murray C D, Dermott S F.\(\textit{ Solar System Dynamics}.\) Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1999: 316
  2. Fowles and Cassiday.\(\textit{Analytical Mechanics}.\) Cengage Learning, 2004
  3. The circular restricted three-body problem. Carlo Nipoti, Dipartimento di Fisica e Astronomia, Universit`a di Bologna
  4. Lecture L18 - Exploring the Neighborhood: the Restricted Three-Body Problem
  5. The restricted three-body problem (1): Equation of motion, The Jacobi Integral, and The Tisserand Relation
  6. The restricted three-body problem (2): Lagrangian points and the stability analysis

entry.title: The Restricted Three-Body Problem Part 3
entry.content:
Lagrangian Equilibrium Points

Looking for the equilibrium points in the rotating coordinate frame, so that its position with respect to the two masses keep from a constant distance.

The equation of the motion in the rotating frame are these equations by moving the centrifugal term (\(n^2x\) and \(n^2y\) ) to the right-hand side of equation.

\(x\)-direction:

\[\begin{equation}\label{eq38.1} (\ddot x  -2n\dot y ) = \frac{\partial{V}}{\partial{x}}= - [ \mu_1 \frac{(\mu_2+x)}{r_1^{3}} + \mu_2 \frac{(x-\mu_1)}{r_2^{3}} ] + n^2x \end{equation}\]

\(y\)-direction:

\[\begin{equation}\label{eq38.2}  (\ddot y + 2n \dot x )= \frac{\partial{V}}{\partial{y}}= (\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} )\cdot y + n^2y \end{equation} \]

\(z\)-direction:

\[\begin{equation}\label{eq38.3} \ddot z = \frac{\partial{V}}{\partial{z}}= - (\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} +  \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} )\cdot  \end{equation} \]

\[\begin{equation}\label{eq39} V(r) = V(x, y, z) \\ = \frac{n^2}{2}(x^2+y^2) + \frac{\mu_1}{r_1}+\frac{\mu_2}{r_2} \end{equation} \]

\[\begin{equation}\label{eq40.1} r_1^2 = (x_1-x)^2 + y^2 + z^2 \\ = (\mu_2+x)^2 + y^2 + z^2 \end{equation} \]

\[\begin{equation}\label{eq40.2} r_2^2 = (x_1-x)^2 + y^2 + z^2 \\ = (x-\mu_1)^2 + y^2 + z^2 \end{equation}\]

where
\(\mu_1=Gm_1=\frac{m_1}{m_1+m_2}\)

\(\mu_2=\bar{\mu}=Gm_1=\frac{m_2}{m_1+m_2}\)

\(\mu_1 + \mu_2 = 1\)

Here, mean motion n is taken as unity \((n=1)\)

The velocity of equilibrium points would be

\[\begin{equation} \dot x = \dot y =\dot z = \ddot x = \ddot y =\ddot z = 0 \end{equation}\]

From Equation , we must have \(z=0\) for the equilibrium points, thus, the equilibrium points are in the orbital plane of two masses. Therefore, based on Equation , Equation and Equation becomes

\[\begin{equation}  \frac{\partial{V}}{\partial{x}} = 0 = -[ \mu_1 \frac{(\mu_2+x)}{r_1^{3}} + \mu_2 \frac{(x-\mu_1)}{r_2^{3}} ] + x \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation}  \frac{\partial{V}}{\partial{y}} = 0 = (\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} )\cdot y + y  \end{equation}\]

Where \(r_1= (\mu_2+1)^2 + y^2, r_2= (x-\mu_1)^2 + y^2\) Equation for y-direction is rewritten as

\[\begin{equation} y \cdot [ 1- (\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} ) ] = 0 \end{equation}\]

So we have two kinds of the solution: > when \(y \neq 0\) is for the triangular points (\(L_4\) and \(L_5\)) > > when \(y = 0\) is for the collinear points (\(L_1, L_2\), and \(L_3\))

Triangular points (when \(y \neq 0\) )

From Equation

\[\begin{equation}  y \cdot [ 1- (\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} ) ] = 0 ~~~~(\because y \neq 0 ) \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} \implies [ 1- (\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} ) ] = 0  \end{equation} \]

Equation is multiplied by \((x+\mu_2)\)

\[\begin{equation} (x+\mu_2)- (x+\mu_2)(\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} ) = 0 \\  (x+\mu_2)- (x+\mu_2)\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} - (x+\mu_2)\frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}}  = 0 \end{equation}\]

From x-direction Equation

\[\begin{equation} x -[ (\mu_2+x) \frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + (x-\mu_1) \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} ] = 0 \\ (\because \mu_1+\mu_2=1, ~~\mu_1 = 1- \mu_2) \\         x - (\mu_2+x) \frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} - (x-1+\mu_2) \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}}  = 0  \\  x-(\mu_2+x) \frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} - (x+\mu_2) \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} = 0  \end{equation}\]

By subtracting Equation from Equation

\[\begin{equation} \mu_2- \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} = 0 \\ \implies r_2 = 1 \end{equation}\]

Equation is multiplied by \((x-\mu_1)\)

\[\begin{equation}  (x-\mu_1)- (x-\mu_1)(\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} ) = 0 \\          (x-\mu_1)- (x-\mu_1)\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} - (x-\mu_1)\frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}}  = 0 \end{equation}\]

From x-direction Equation

\[\begin{equation} x -[ (\mu_2+x) \frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} + (x-\mu_1) \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} ] = 0 \\ (\because \mu_2 = 1- \mu_1) \\         x - (1- \mu_1+x) \frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} - (x- \mu_1) \frac{ \mu_2}{r_2^{3}}  = 0  \\         x-(x-\mu_1) \frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}}-\frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} - (x-\mu_1) \frac{\mu_2}{r_2^{3}} = 0 \end{equation}\]

By subtracting Equation from Equation

\[\begin{equation}  -\mu_1+ \frac{\mu_1}{r_1^{3}} = 0 \\ \implies r_1 = 1 \end{equation}\]

So \(r_1=r_2 = 1\), it is the distance between the two masses. Then, let's find the coordinate of \(L_4\) and \(L_5\)

From Equation

\[\begin{equation}  r_1^2 = (\mu_2+x)^2 + y^2 = 1 \\        \mu_2^2 + 2\mu_2 x + x^2 +y^2 = 1 \end{equation}\]

From Equation

\[\begin{equation} r_2^2 = (x-\mu_1)^2 + y^2 = 1 \\        x^2 - 2x\mu_1 + \mu_1^2 +y^2 = 1 \\        (\because \mu_1 = 1- \mu_2) \\       x^2 - 2x(1-\mu_2) + (1-\mu_2)^2 +y^2 = 1 \\        x^2 -2x + 2\mu_2x +1 - 2\mu_2 + \mu_2^2 + y^2 = 1 \end{equation}\]

By subtracting Equation from Equation

\[\begin{equation} 1-2\mu_2-2x =0 \\ \implies 2(\mu_2+x) = 1 \\ \implies x=\frac{1}{2}-\mu_2 \end{equation}\]

Substituting \(x = \frac{1}{2}-\mu_2\) into Equation

\[\begin{equation} (\mu_2+x)^2 + y^2 = 1 \\ \implies [\mu_2+ (\frac{1}{2}-\mu_2) ]^2+y^2 = 1 \\ \implies y^2 = 1- \frac{1}{4} = \frac{3}{4} \\ \implies y = \frac{\pm \sqrt{3}}{2}  \end{equation}\]

Finally, we got the position of \(L_4\) and \(L_5\)

\(L_4\) Leading point: \(x=\frac{1}{2}-\mu_2\), \(y=\frac{+\sqrt{3}}{2}\)
\(L_5\) Trailing point: \(x=\frac{1}{2}-\mu_2\), \(y=\frac{- \sqrt{3}}{2}\)

Location of Lagrangian point \(L_4\) and \(L_5\)

Collinear points (when \(y = 0\) )

Equilibrium points lie along x-axis when \(y = 0\) , and satisfy \(\frac{\partial V}{\partial x} = 0\).

There are three solutions correspond to the "collinear Lagrangian equilibrium points" shown as Figure .

  • \(L_1\) point: between the mass \(\mu_1\) and \(\mu_2\)
  • \(L_2\) point: outside the mass \(\mu_2\) on the positive \(x\)-axis
  • \(L_3\) point: outside the mass \(\mu_1\) on the negative \(x\)-axis

Location of Lagrangian point \(L_1\), \(L_2\), and \(L_3\)

For the convenience of later calculation, we rewrite \(V(r)\), \(\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}\), and \(\frac{\partial V}{\partial y}\) as following: From Equation and Equation ,

\[\begin{equation}  r_1^2 = (\mu_2+x)^2 + y^2 + z^2 \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation}  r_2^2 =(x-\mu_1)^2 + y^2 + z^2 \end{equation}\]

Equation is multiplied by \(\mu_1\), and \(z=0\)

\[\begin{equation} \mu_1r_1^2 = \mu_1(\mu_2+x)^2 + \mu_1y^2 \end{equation}\]

Equation is multiplied by \(\mu_2\), and \(z=0\)

\[\begin{equation} \mu_2r_2^2 = \mu_2(x-\mu_1)^2 + \mu_2y^2 \end{equation}\]

By adding Equation to Equation

\[\begin{equation} \mu_1r_1^2 + \mu_2r_2^2 = y^2(\mu_1+\mu_2) + \mu_1(x^2 +2\mu_2x + \mu_2^2) + \mu_2(x^2 -2\mu_1x + \mu_1^2) \\ ~~~~~(\because \mu_1 + \mu_2 = 1) \\ = x^2 + y^2 + \mu_1^2\mu_2 + \mu_1\mu_2^2 \\ = x^2 + y^2 + \mu_1\mu_2(\mu_1+\mu_2) \\ \implies \mu_1r_1^2 + \mu_2r_2^2 = x^2 + y^2 + \mu_1\mu_2 \end{equation}\]

Based on Equation , Equation becomes

\[\begin{equation} V(r) = \frac{1}{2}(x^2+y^2) + \frac{\mu_1}{r_1}+\frac{\mu_2}{r_2} \\ = \frac{1}{2}(\mu_1r_1^2 + \mu_2r_2^2 - \mu_1\mu_2) + \frac{\mu_1}{r_1}+\frac{\mu_2}{r_2} \\ = \frac{-1}{2}\mu_1\mu_2 +\mu_1\frac{r_1^2}{2}+\mu_2\frac{r_2^2}{2} + \frac{\mu_1}{r_1}+\frac{\mu_2}{r_2} \\ = \mu_1(\frac{1}{r_1}+\frac{r_1^2}{2}) + \mu_2(\frac{1}{r_2}+\frac{r_2^2}{2})-\frac{1}{2}\mu_1\mu_2 \\ \implies V(r) = \mu_1(\frac{1}{r_1}+\frac{r_1^2}{2}) + \mu_2(\frac{1}{r_2}+\frac{r_2^2}{2})-\frac{1}{2}\mu_1\mu_2 \end{equation}\]

According to Equation , \(\frac{\partial V}{\partial x}\) is rewritten as

\[\begin{equation} \frac{1}{(2+\beta)^2} = \frac{1}{(4+4\beta+4\beta^2)} \\ = \frac{1}{4(1+\beta+\frac{1}{4}\beta^2)} \\ = \frac{1}{4}( 1+nx + \frac{n(n-1)}{2!}x^2) \\ (\because n=-1~, ~ x=\beta+ \frac{1}{4}\beta^2, \\ x^2 =(\beta+ \frac{1}{4}\beta^2)^2 = \beta^2 + \frac{1}{2}\beta^3 +\frac{1}{16}\beta^4 ~~) \\ = \frac{1}{4} (1-\beta-\frac{1}{4}\beta^2 + \beta^2 +\frac{1}{2}\beta^3 + \frac{1}{16}\beta^4 ) \\ = \frac{1}{4} - \frac{1}{4}\beta + \frac{3}{16}\beta^2 +\frac{1}{8}\beta^3 +\frac{1}{64}\beta^4 \\ = \frac{1}{4} - \frac{1}{4}\beta + \frac{3}{16}\beta^2 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^3) \end{equation}\]

Substituting the result of Equation and into Equation

\[\begin{equation} \frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1} = [\frac{-1}{(1+\beta)^2}+ (1+\beta)] \cdot [\frac{1}{(2+\beta)^2}+(2+\beta))]^{-1} \\ = ( -1+ 2\beta - 3\beta^3 +1+ \beta) \cdot (\frac{1}{4} - \frac{1}{4}\beta + \frac{3}{16}\beta^2 -2-\beta)^{-1} \\ = (3\beta -3\beta^2)(\frac{-7}{4}-\frac{5}{4}\beta+\frac{3}{16}\beta^2 )^{-1} \end{equation}\]

The part of Equation

\[\begin{equation} (\frac{-7}{4}-\frac{5}{4}\beta+\frac{3}{16}\beta^2 )^{-1} = \frac{1}{(\frac{-7}{4}-\frac{5}{4}\beta+\frac{3}{16}\beta^2 )} \\ = \frac{1}{\frac{-7}{4}(1+\frac{5}{7}\beta-\frac{3}{28}\beta^2)} \\ = \frac{-4}{7}\frac{1}{(1+\frac{5}{7}\beta-\frac{3}{28}\beta^2)} \\ = \frac{-4}{7}( 1+nx + \frac{n(n-1)}{2!}x^2) \\ (\because n= -1~, ~ x=\frac{5}{7}\beta-\frac{3}{28}\beta^2, \\ ~~~ x^2 =(\frac{5}{7}\beta-\frac{3}{28}\beta^2)^2 = \frac{35}{49}\beta^2 - \frac{30}{196}\beta^3 +\frac{9}{784}\beta^4 ~~) \\ = \frac{-4}{7}[1-\frac{5}{7}\beta+\frac{3}{28}\beta^2 + \frac{1}{2}(-1)(-2)(\frac{35}{49}\beta^2 - \frac{30}{196}\beta^3 +\frac{9}{784}\beta^4) ] \\ = \frac{-4}{7}[1-\frac{5}{7}\beta+\frac{3}{28}\beta^2 + \frac{35}{49}\beta^2 - \frac{30}{196}\beta^3 +\frac{9}{784}\beta^4 ] \\ = \frac{-4}{7}[1-\frac{5}{7}\beta+ \frac{3}{28}\beta^2 + \frac{35}{49}\beta^2 - \frac{30}{196}\beta^3 + \frac{9}{784}\beta^4 ] \\ = \frac{-4}{7}[1-\frac{5}{7}\beta+ \frac{161}{1372}\beta^2 - \frac{30}{196}\beta^3 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^5) ] \end{equation}\]

Substituting the result of Equation into Equation

\[\begin{equation} \frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1} = (3\beta -3\beta^2)(\frac{-7}{4}-\frac{5}{4}\beta+\frac{3}{16}\beta^2 )^{-1} \\ = 3(\beta -\beta^2) \cdot \frac{-4}{7}[1-\frac{5}{7}\beta+ \frac{161}{1372}\beta^2 - \frac{30}{196}\beta^3 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^5) \\ = \frac{-12}{7}[\beta - \frac{5}{7}\beta^2 + \frac{161}{1372}\beta^3 - \beta + \frac{5}{7}\beta^3- \frac{161}{1372}\beta^4 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^5)] \\ = \frac{-12}{7}[\beta - \frac{12}{7}\beta^2 + \frac{163}{196}\beta^3 -\frac{161}{1372}\beta^4 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^5) ] \\ = \frac{-12}{7}\beta + \frac{144}{49}\beta^2 - \frac{1956}{1372}\beta^3 + \frac{1932}{9604}\beta^4 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^5) \\ \implies \frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1} =\frac{-12}{7}\beta + \frac{144}{49}\beta^2-\frac{1956}{1372}\beta^3 + \frac{1932}{9604}\beta^4 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^5) \end{equation}\]

Let \(\alpha = \frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1}\), and \(k= \frac{12}{7}\beta\) , the higher terms of Equation is neglected, because the value id small.

\[\begin{equation} \alpha = \frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1} =\frac{-12}{7}\beta + \frac{144}{49}\beta^2 -\frac{1956}{1372}\beta^3 + \frac{1932}{9604}\beta^4 + \mathcal{O}(\beta^5) \\ = \frac{-12}{7}\beta + \frac{144}{49}\beta^2 +\mathcal{O}(\beta^3) \\ = -k + k^2 +\mathcal{O}(k^3) \end{equation}\]

Using Lagrangian’s inversion method to invert the series expansions in Equation

\[\begin{equation} k = -\alpha + k^2 +\mathcal{O}(k^3) \\ = -\alpha + (1)\cdot \phi(k) ~~~~(\because e = 1 ) \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} \implies \phi(k) = k^2 + \mathcal{O}(k^3) \end{equation}\]

And hence

\[\begin{equation} \implies \phi(\alpha) = \alpha^2 + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^3) \end{equation}\]

\[\begin{equation} \frac{12}{7}\beta = k = -\alpha + \alpha^2 + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^3) \\ \implies \beta = \frac{-7}{12}\alpha + \frac{7}{12}\alpha^2 + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^3) \\ = \frac{-7}{12} (\frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1}) + \frac{7}{12}((\frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1})^2) + \mathcal{O}((\frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1})^3) \end{equation}\]

From previous condition,

\[\begin{equation} r_1 = 1 + \beta \\ = x + \mu_2 \\ \implies x = -r_1 - \mu_2 \\ = -(1+\beta) - \mu_2 \\ = -1 +(\frac{-7}{12}\alpha + \frac{7}{12}\alpha^2) + \mathcal{O}(\alpha^3) - \mu_2 \\ = -1 - \mu_2 + \frac{-7}{12} (\frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1}) - \frac{7}{12}((\frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1})^2) + \mathcal{O}((\frac{\mu_2}{\mu_1})^3) \end{equation}\]

This is location of \(L_3\) point on the negative \(x\)-axis.
